items.title: Geocoder Gives Empty CountryName in Python
items.body:
For italian numbers there is no country name
```py
geocoder.country_name_for_number(phonenumbers.parse("+3936855554284"), 'en')
```
The above gives a empty string

But on the [JAVA DEMO](https://libphonenumber.appspot.com/phonenumberparser?number=%2B3936855554284)
Phone Number region | IT
-- | --

Ideally, the country name should be given as Italy in the above function

items.title: Issue parsing/formatting GB "special numbers"
items.body:
The following numbers, when parsed via https://libphonenumber.appspot.com/ (using GB as the default country code), all yield the same result.

8001111
08001111
+448001111
+4408001111

the result is:

E164             +448001111
INTERNATIONAL    +44 800 1111
NATIONAL         0800 1111

the python library, up until 8.7.1, returned the same result. Starting with 8.8.0, a leading zero, if present, is reproduced in the NATIONAL format, yielding 2 different results. If the leading zero is omitted, the results match the expected ones above. If a leading zero is present, I get the following result:

E164             +4408001111 (should not be a zero in here)
INTERNATIONAL    +44 08001111 (should not be a zero in here)
NATIONAL         08001111

It looks like the issue is the length check, which now fails to strip the leading zero if the length check returns ValidationResult.IS_POSSIBLE_LOCAL_ONLY.

items.title: Fix simple typo: beween -> between
items.body:
There is a small typo in python/phonenumbers/phonenumberutil.py.
Should read `between` rather than `beween`.

items.title: Over Aggressive Matching for US numbers
items.body:
I am trying to parse only US phone numbers out of a document that contains numbers from multiple countries - mainly US, and the non US numbers are in E164 format which I will grab in a later parse
The issue is I am getting international numbers in E164 format found in the parse, and also they are marked as valid numbers even though the parse shows their country code to be something other than 1.
(the offending phone numbers in question are +420 222 888 888, +44 20 7493 1232 and +36 1 486 5000.)
This is not reproducible in the Java demo: http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/phonenumberparser?number=44+20+7483+1232&country=US
In the above link you can see isValidNumber is False.
To reproduce:
```
# first pass for US numbers
for match in PhoneNumberMatcher(content, "US"):
    parsed = parse(match.raw_string, "US")
    if is_valid_number(parsed):
        print(match.number)
# second pass for other numbers in E164 format
for match in PhoneNumberMatcher(content, "US"):
    parsed = parse(match.raw_string, "US")
    if is_valid_number(parsed):
        print(match.number) 
```
I would eventually add a filter on the second loop to not return numbers which were previously found as american.
example content:
```
Dr. Paul can be reached at +420 222 888 888.  His assistant's personal phone number is 800-922-8228, but sometimes you can call him at 9163249078.  His associate can be reached before 9am at +1-202-435-4325.  When he is traveling you can try his international cell at +44 20 7493 1232 or his wife's international number at +36 1 486 5000.
```

items.title: RTL phone rendering issue.
items.body:
Hi,

Using Django 3.0 as a Framework, and python-phonenumbers to render phone numbers in Django template.

LTR work great, but when the web page is in RTL (Right to Left = Arabic langauge) there's an issue rendrering phone numbers.

Ex : Phone number : 0779537579
```python
parsed = phonenumbers.parse('0779537579', 'SA')
phonenumbers.format_number(parsed, phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.NATIONAL)
```
-----
1) Phone rendering in LTR : 0779 53 75 79
2) Phone rendrering in RTL : 79 75 53 0779

Is there a workaround for this or an option to say that this is a RTL one ???, I'm I missing something ?

PS:if the phone number does't have a space it is well rendered in the tempalte, wich (the sapce) was made by the phonenumbers(PhoneNumberFormat.NATIONAL).

Amazing library
Hope to hear from you soon.

Thank you

items.title: DeprecationWarning: Flags not at the start of the expression
items.body:
Happens every time when I run unit tests that call phonenumbers.match 
python 3.6, probably 
```
 DeprecationWarning: Flags not at the start of the expression '(?:[(\\[（［+＋][-x‐-―−ー' (truncated)
    _REGEX_FLAGS)

```
This similar issue has a few recommendations to resolve the same issue
https://github.com/gboeing/osmnx/issues/285

items.title: Failure on long number with italian_leading_zero
items.body:
Phone number `+1 0086-592-5627191` [is correctly rejected](http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/phonenumberparser?number=%2B1+0086-592-5627191) in upstream project.

However, in the [latest version of this project](https://github.com/daviddrysdale/python-phonenumbers/releases/tag/v8.10.15), there is an error:

```
$ ipython
Python 3.7.2 (default, Jan 19 2019, 21:31:41)
Type 'copyright', 'credits' or 'license' for more information
IPython 7.5.0 -- An enhanced Interactive Python. Type '?' for help.

In [1]: import phonenumbers

In [2]: phonenumbers.__version__
Out[2]: '8.10.15'

In [3]: phonenumbers.is_possible_number("+1 0086-592-5627191")
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-b75dc190f6df> in <module>
----> 1 phonenumbers.is_possible_number("+1 0086-592-5627191")

~/.pyenv/versions/3.7.2/envs/vv37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/phonenumbers/phonenumberutil.py in is_possible_number(numobj)
   2214
   2215     """
-> 2216     result = is_possible_number_with_reason(numobj)
   2217     return (result == ValidationResult.IS_POSSIBLE or
   2218             result == ValidationResult.IS_POSSIBLE_LOCAL_ONLY)

~/.pyenv/versions/3.7.2/envs/vv37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/phonenumbers/phonenumberutil.py in is_possible_number_with_reason(numobj)
   2315
   2316 def is_possible_number_with_reason(numobj):
-> 2317     return is_possible_number_for_type_with_reason(numobj, PhoneNumberType.UNKNOWN)
   2318
   2319

~/.pyenv/versions/3.7.2/envs/vv37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/phonenumbers/phonenumberutil.py in is_possible_number_for_type_with_reason(numobj, numtype)
   2350     is possible
   2351     """
-> 2352     national_number = national_significant_number(numobj)
   2353     country_code = numobj.country_code
   2354     # Note: For regions that share a country calling code, like NANPA numbers,

~/.pyenv/versions/3.7.2/envs/vv37/lib/python3.7/site-packages/phonenumbers/phonenumberutil.py in national_significant_number(numobj)
   1587     # national prefix.
   1588     national_number = U_EMPTY_STRING
-> 1589     if numobj.italian_leading_zero:
   1590         num_zeros = numobj.number_of_leading_zeros
   1591         if num_zeros is None:

AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'italian_leading_zero'
```

items.title: How to create a phone number object without knowing country code
items.body:
Hi,
I am trying to  validate some phone numbers, just need clarification on building the phone number object eg: ph.parse(phone_no_string, "AU"). I am in Australia.

We have numbers from across the globe in our database, there is no consistent format, we have: 

- international numbers with "+""country_code""number", 

- some with just "country_code""number", 

- some just "area_code""number" (local numbers) and 

- some just "fixed_line_number" (which are valid if dialed locally within the state), they are missing the area code, that is the reason for validation fail, which is fine. 

Now when building the phone number object, we can use "ZZ" if the number starts with "plus""country_code" but not all the numbers have that format, so how to build the phone number object with the right country code without knowing that in advance?

I have used "AU" for parsing all numbers as majority were from Australia, which actually yielded good results. Most of the international numbers parsed correctly because they were prefixed with "+" and geographical info was correct.  But I dont know if this is the correct approach. 
I am just trying to understand what the right approach should be. it would be great if someone can give me pointers on how to use this library. 


thanks, 
yudi

items.title: Parsing error of chinese number start with 191
items.body:
As follow, when parsing number `19147005807` in region `CN`, somehow, the country_code turn to `58` and the national_number became `7`, but it should be `country_code=86, national_number=19147005807`

Here are cases to verify that

``` python
>>> import phonenumbers
>>> phone = phonenumbers.parse("+8619147005807", None)
>>> phone
PhoneNumber(country_code=86, national_number=19147005807, extension=None, italian_leading_zero=None, number_of_leading_zeros=None, country_code_source=0, preferred_domestic_carrier_code=None)
>>> phone = phonenumbers.parse("+8619147005807", 'CN')
>>> phone
PhoneNumber(country_code=86, national_number=19147005807, extension=None, italian_leading_zero=None, number_of_leading_zeros=None, country_code_source=0, preferred_domestic_carrier_code=None)
>>> phone = phonenumbers.parse("19147005807", 'CN')
>>> phone
PhoneNumber(country_code=58, national_number=7, extension=None, italian_leading_zero=True, number_of_leading_zeros=None, country_code_source=0, preferred_domestic_carrier_code=None)
>>> phone = phonenumbers.parse("19163223660", 'CN')
>>> phone
PhoneNumber(country_code=86, national_number=19163223660, extension=None, italian_leading_zero=None, number_of_leading_zeros=None, country_code_source=0, preferred_domestic_carrier_code=None)
>>>
```

items.title: Compile with centos6
items.body:
Please do not report issues that can be reproduced with the [upstream Java project](https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber): if your issue can be reproduced with the [online Java demo](http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/), report your [problem upstream](https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#checklist-before-filing-an-issue) instead.

In particular, any changes to the phonenumber metadata or to the API should be reported upstream rather than here.  Only issues or contributions that are **specific to the Python version** are relevant here.

Hello,
Can we compile your software with centos6 (protobuf 2.3)
Thanks

items.title: PhoneMetadata.same_mobile_and_fixed_line_pattern is incorrectly derived
items.body:
This line compares the whole number descriptions:

https://github.com/daviddrysdale/python-phonenumbers/blob/168a1f1e80502544089bc0739670a324730c09bb/python/phonenumbers/phonemetadata.py#L452

But upstream only compares the patterns:

https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber/blob/7cfcd7fe533d82a45c441c0b5f01400435f0dc79/tools/java/common/src/com/google/i18n/phonenumbers/BuildMetadataFromXml.java#L510

For `DK` this was broken in v8.9 because although the patterns were equal the example numbers were different:

https://github.com/daviddrysdale/python-phonenumbers/blob/ad34567d0275be3e6c1de2d72f7b015c315f2fe3/python/phonenumbers/data/region_DK.py

The metadata for `DK` no longer triggers this bug, I believe that the code itself is still broken, and that the same issue could arise again?

items.title: Regex performance using re2
items.body:
Since we are heavily relying on regex here, it makes sense to focus on performance.
Google released re2 https://github.com/google/re2
Intel released hypersacan https://www.hyperscan.io/

items.title: Make the __repr__ method look similar to SRE_Match's __repr__ method
items.body:
Instead of doing 
```python
    def __repr__(self):
        return (unicod("PhoneNumberMatch(start=%r, raw_string=%r, numobj=%r)") %
                (self.start,
                 self.raw_string,
                 self.number))

    def __unicode__(self):
        return unicod("PhoneNumberMatch [%s,%s) %s") % (self.start, self.end, self.raw_string)
```

do something similar to re.match's __repr__ method and do 
`"<phonenumbers.PhoneNumberMatch; start={}, end={}, raw_string={}>".format(self.start, self.end, self.raw_string)`
maybe even convert the start and end into a tuple and have it be span?

items.title: Wrong names of Congo in geocoder
items.body:
```
>>> phone = phonenumbers.parse('+243 1123 32 12', None)
>>> geocoder.country_name_for_number(phone, 'en')
u'The Democratic Republic Of Congo'
```

"The Democratic Republic Of Congo" is wrong name, the right is "Democratic Republic of the Congo".

```
>>> phone = phonenumbers.parse('+242 1123 32 12', None)
>>> geocoder.country_name_for_number(phone, 'en')
u'Congo'
```
"Congo" is wrong too, real name is "Republic of the Congo"

items.title: Making a standalone executable?
items.body:
I've written a batch program using phonenumbers. On my Windows system with Python 3.6.4 installed, it works as intended, but I'd like to redistribute it as a standalone Windows executable. However, I'm hitting two barriers: first, I'm a rank beginner with Python, and the details of the Python environment are still a slog for me. Second, the .EXE program throws an exception in trying to dynamically load country data to parse a number, and I haven't managed to figure out how to incorporate dynamically loaded modules into a standalone executable. (The failure was in a "try" clause, so it took me a while to locate it.) My own system has all the memory I'd need to preload all parsing data up front, so I'd prefer to do things that way.

Solutions, suggestions, hints, thoughts? A fully-worked example somewhere?

items.title: DeprecationWarning in python 3.6
items.body:
With python 3.6, there is a deprecation warning about regex flags not being at the start of the expression.

```bash
~/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/phonenumbers/phonenumbermatcher.py:122: DeprecationWarning: Flags not at the start of the expression (?:[(\[（［+＋][-x‐-―−ー (truncated)
  _REGEX_FLAGS)
/usr/lib/python3.6/re.py:301: DeprecationWarning: Flags not at the start of the expression (?:[(\[（［+＋][-x‐-―−ー (truncated)
  p = sre_compile.compile(pattern, flags)

```

I think this is the related python discussion: https://bugs.python.org/issue22493

items.title: Argentina phone numbers are formatted incorrectly
items.body:
A range of perfectly reachable numbers in Argentina (+54) are formatted incorrectly.

Here's an example number: +5450490000 (An actual phone number I have is a few last digits different from that example to avoid disclosing personal information). The issue appears across a large range of numbers +5499999999 - +5400000000.

```python
>>> parsed = phonenumbers.parse('+5450490000')
>>> phonenumbers.format_number(parsed, phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.INTERNATIONAL)
'+54 NA'
```

The number appears to be [invalid](http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/phonenumberparser?number=%2B5499999999) in [upstream library](https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber/issues/1697), but until they fix it, `phonenumbers` should throw exception instead of silently producing incorrect result.

A quick investigation on my end shows that the last well-behaving version was 7.7.3.

items.body:
Despite the demo showing that the phone number +972559416222 is a valid number, version 8.2.0 of the python library's is_valid_number returns false for this number. 

Demo result can be seen here: https://libphonenumber.appspot.com/phonenumberparser?number=%2B972559416222&country=US

items.title: International number incorrect parse
items.body:
```
In: phonenumbers.format_number(phonenumbers.parse('+1 61447442511', 'US'), phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.INTERNATIONAL)
Out: '+1 61447442511'
```

```
In: phonenumbers.format_number(phonenumbers.parse('+1 510-599-2010', 'US'), phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.INTERNATIONAL)
Out: '+1 510-599-2010'
```
Why "out" is in this two cases are in different formats.

items.title: PyPI Not Updated
items.body: I'm not sure the mechanics behind how PyPI gets updated, but it's still serving [version 7.5.2](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/phonenumbers). Is there a required manual step to update it to version 7.6.0?

items.title: Wheel format
items.body:
http://pythonwheels.com/

Right now, only the `tar.gz` file is being distributed on PyPI for [phonenumbers](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/phonenumbers) and [phonenumberslite](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/phonenumberslite), which isn't _that much_ of an issue, but it does add some time to installing the package.

This package should be compatible with the Wheel format, considering it doesn't appear to have any C dependencies and it is compatible with both Python 2 and 3. As a result, you should only need to generate a universal wheel and then everyone (on all systems) will get the ability to install python-phonenumbers with just the wheel, without having to do any extra work.

items.title: DeprecationWarning in Python 3.5
items.body:
Python 3.5 shows "DeprecationWarning: bad escape \p" for the regular expression on line 160 of phonenumbermatcher.py.

See http://bugs.python.org/issue23622 for the change in Python that added the warning.

items.title: prefix 173 needs to be added for CN
items.body:
According to ITU standard, from Oct 1 2015, mobile number starting with 173 is a valid range in CN (http://www.itu.int/oth/T020200002B/en), owning by China Telecom

This has been an accepted issue in libphonenumber googlei18n/libphonenumber#947

items.title: New Brazil mobile numbers are failing is_valid_number() method.
items.body:
``` bash
>>> n = phonenumbers.parse("+5586998975814")
>>> phonenumbers.is_valid_number(n)
False
```

According to [National Numbering Plan for Brazil](http://www.itu.int/dms_pub/itu-t/oth/02/02/T020200001D0001PDFE.pdf) , mobile numbers have been slowly migrating from  '+55 XX XXXX XXXX' to '+55 XX 9XXXX XXXX'. Eventually these numbers could be 2-9. 

The library recognizes this to be a valid mobile number: http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/

items.title: National numbers outside the US and Canada are always prefixed with 01
items.body:
When formatting a number from outside the US or Canada as a national number, this library always prepend a `01` in front.

Here's an example with a number from Mexico

``` python
num = phonenumbers.parse('+523222222099')
phonenumbers.format_number(num, phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.NATIONAL)
// OUT: u'01 322 222 2099'
```

I'd expect the national number to be `322 222 2099`.

```
PhoneNumber(country_code=1, national_number=3432640000, extension=None, italian_leading_zero=True, number_of_leading_zeros=None, country_code_source=None, preferred_domestic_carrier_code=None)
>>> phonenumbers.format_number(x, phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.E164)
u'+103432640000'
```

items.body:
These two numbers in Argentina return false for is_valid_number on branch release-5.7b2:

``` python
>>> import phonenumbers
>>> x = phonenumbers.parse("+540348215617137", "AR")
>>> phonenumbers.is_valid_number(x)
False
>>>
>>> y = phonenumbers.parse("0344615614207", "AR")
>>> phonenumbers.is_valid_number(y)
False
>>>
```

In both cases, http://libphonenumber.appspot.com/ regards these as MOBILE numbers.

items.title: Geocoding results in Traditional Chinese
items.body:
How the original java library parse language code
- `zh` -> simplified chinese
- `zh-tw` -> traditional chinese
- `zh_Hant` -> unknown locale, use english

But python library 
- `zh` -> simplified chinese
- `zh-tw` unknown locale, use english
- `zh_Hant` -> traditional chinese

Below is the code demonstrating the problem 

```
>>> from phonenumbers.geocoder import area_description_for_number
>>> print area_description_for_number(phonenumbers.parse("0800080123", "TW"), "zh")
屏东
>>> print area_description_for_number(phonenumbers.parse("0800080123", "TW"), "zh_tw")
Pingtung  // should be 屏東
>>> print area_description_for_number(phonenumbers.parse("0800080123", "TW"), "zh_Hant")
屏東 // should be Pingtung
```

> > Just for reference 
> > - 屏东 <- simplified chinese 
> > - 屏東 <- traditional chinese

items.title: Porting to Python 3
items.body:
Hello, this isn't really an issue, but I don't know where else to talk about this.

I need to use phonenumbers with Python 3.3.

The README talks about:
- running 2to3, but I'm not sure how well that plays with pip.
- the python3 branch, but the wording doesn't inspire a lot of confidence.

Current porting efforts keep compatibility with Python 2.5, which makes the shared-source approach one order of magnitude harder than targeting Python 2.6 as the lowest supported version.

Since I have some experience with porting to Python 3 (I ported Django, among other things), I tried to redo the porting for 2.6+ and 3.3+, which is all I need. It just required the following steps:
- making relative imports explicit eg. `from .util import ...`
- changing `try` blocks to use the `except ... as ...` syntax
- removing long literals; I'm not sure why they're used instead of plain integers; this change makes a lot of noise in the tests
- replacing `long` by `int`
- adding `text_type` (`unicode` or `str`) and `xrange` (`xrange` or `range`) for compatibility
- replacing `sys.maxint` by something else -- I used `sys.maxsize` but that's semantically wrong, another hardcoded constant would be better

At this point, the library appears to work ie. I can reproduce the examples in the documentation. However, for some reason, the tests (python setup.py test) fail massively, as if no data could be found for any country.

Finally I suggest the following fix to UnicodeMixin:

```
 class UnicodeMixin(object):  # pragma no cover
     """Define __str__ operator in terms of __unicode__ for Python 2/3"""
+    # Emulate the way the interpreter looks up magic methods
     if sys.version_info >= (3, 0):
-        __str__ = lambda x: x.__unicode__()
+        __str__ = lambda x: type(x).__unicode__(x)
     else:
-        __str__ = lambda x: unicode(x).encode('utf-8')
+        __str__ = lambda x: type(x).__unicode__(x).encode('utf-8')
```

It shouldn't matter except in weird subclassing schemes.

This isn't really actionnable, and I expect you to close this issue once you've read it, but I found it interesting to share this experience. 

[EDIT] I accidentally sumbitted the issue while I was writing, I've completed my description since then.

items.title: PhoneNumber class methods and attributes
items.body:
Is there a reason why PhoneNumber class doesn't have methods and attributes for validation and formatting the phone number? For templates and such it would seem easier to just write `phone_number.international` or `phone_number.is_valid()` instead of using `phonenumbers.is_valid_number(phone_number)` for example.

This seems to me like a design issue or maybe there's something I'm missing. Hopefully someone can clarify me.

Anyways I ended up writing my own PhoneNumber class. I'm not sure if there's a reason why the class was not designed this way.

``` python
import phonenumbers

class PhoneNumber(phonenumbers.phonenumber.PhoneNumber):
    def __init__(self, raw_number, country_code=None):
        self._phone_number = phonenumbers.parse(raw_number, country_code)
        super(PhoneNumber, self).__init__(
            country_code=self._phone_number.country_code,
            national_number=self._phone_number.national_number,
            extension=self._phone_number.extension,
            italian_leading_zero=self._phone_number.italian_leading_zero,
            raw_input=self._phone_number.raw_input,
            country_code_source=self._phone_number.country_code_source,
            preferred_domestic_carrier_code=
            self._phone_number.preferred_domestic_carrier_code
        )
        self.national = phonenumbers.format_number(
            self._phone_number,
            phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.NATIONAL
        )
        self.international = phonenumbers.format_number(
            self._phone_number,
            phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.INTERNATIONAL
        )
        self.e164 = phonenumbers.format_number(
            self._phone_number,
            phonenumbers.PhoneNumberFormat.E164
        )

    def is_valid(self):
        return phonenumbers.is_valid_number(self._phone_number)
```

items.title: Problems with excessive memory usage
items.body:
We are using phonennumbers, in order to be able to normalize phone numbers from 0660123123 for example to +48660123123  ITU-T E.164 format, knowing the ISO countr code  the number is from (regardless of the format of the original number). This is a great piece of code which took us almost no time to integrate. Thanks for the porting work !!!
We noticed however after merging our code with this changes and deploying to rthe production server, suddenly our site stopped responding. We reverted back quickly and tried a few changes, and finally we narrowed it down to single line of code:

```
import phonenumbers
```

It seems that the library is awfully memory-hungry. After further checking - we found our that just importing phonenumbers increases the memory used by application by 50+MB. This is a django app we are running and before the import it was about 40 MB, so this is quite significant increase. Moreover it seems that there are some very bad effects, if the memory starts being swapped out to disc. Instead of observed moderate slowdown of the app, it basically stops responding. It seems that the code in your library is really hard trying to scan through the whole memory it's using and tries to bring the whole data back to memory....  Which - when you run several processes in parallell - can be disastrous because it seems that the processes are continuously swapping each other in back to memory/out to disk and the whole application stops responding.

Just to give a bit of background: we are running our django app in "controlled" environment of heroku where one "dyno" only has 512 MB of ram, and we are using gunicorn in front, that spawns several worker processes - this is in order to get scalability and be able to handle several  requests in parallel per "dyno". So far we could easily run 4 workers per dyno but after adding phonenenumbers, the swapping out (and putting the site to halt) kicks in already at 2nd worker. We are running some other software there, like pgbouncer and the os itself takes a bit of memory, so we do not have all 512 MB available - it looks like we have around 180 MB. Which means for us that basically in order to get the same throughput with phonennumbers, we need to get 4x more dynos(!) (and on heroku you pay per dyno(!)). Obviously that's not really acceptable :-1:  . I know you mentioned at your wiki page that you are not that conscious about memory as the original Java library, because the library should be used in server environment... but it seems that assumption is not true for us, unfortunately.

We are looking into ways to solve it, so i have the following question. Is there a way to run the library in less-memory hungry mode ? How do the guys in Java lib did it? Maybe we can help somehow in moving it in the right direction of being less memory hungry? I guess the memory used comes from the need of doing type-ahead typing etc. features which are very useful for a mobile app, but less (if at all) useful for python code run at the server side (seems better to use it in javascript), so maybe that part can be trimmed down (or even completely removed, if this is the culprit). We only need one functionality: get a phone number and iso CC of where the number is from and produce ITU-T E.164 formatted number  (regardless of the format of the original number), so maybe there is a way we could simply remove the other code and use the rest?

Any help greatly appreciated.

items.title: plans to implement getNumberType?
items.body: Do you have plans to implement the getNumberType method from libphonenumber? This would be very useful...
